data.title: Skip minified files when searching
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: 10.12.3

I don't think anyone want to read minified files. Searching text in files can skip those minified css, js files by default, add a setting to enable/disable this feature.

Steps of use case:

1. cmd + shift + f to open the search
2. Type any text to search the text in files

data.title: Provide a easy way to get rid of the annoying git version warning

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:
$ code --version
1.11.1
d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39

- OS Version:
Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open vscode
2. An annoying warning about git version being 1.9 something appears.

It is nice information to have, and its a good warning to show once, or twice, but please don't show it *every* time I open code. That is very annoying.

I don't really care that much if the git features in vscode can work better with 2.x. I do not use these features that much and prefer to use other gui and cli tools anyways. Also, I prefer to stick with the version of git that comes with my Os's package manager by default.

You should assume that is just what some people are going to want to do and perpetually pestering them to upgrade git is not very nice. 

So please, give me an easy and obvious way to dismiss the warning **once and for all** so it doesn't pop back up the next time I open vscode.

data.title: If there is two launch tasks with the same name, we can't pick the correct one
Code asks users to choose the runtime twice if launch.json doesn't exist
data.body:
Ref https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22279

* Open a project which has no `.vscode/launch.json` file. 
* Press F5, a prompt window shows up and ask to set runtime. Choose Nodejs
* Error message: Attribute program doesn't exist.
* Click "Open Launch.json"
* The prompt window shows up again and ask to set runtime.

The prompt window should not show up twice.

data.title: Tweak HTML Preview Styling
data.body:
Two changes:

* Changes the logic from 41467b74b7e486f3a5857d3cc0ab15d85a2b7a84 to make the padding customizable. The default 20px padding is preserved, but extensions that use the preview should now customize this. This allows html preview page background colors to correctly fill the entire frame and for the content to be properly centered. I tested that #5883 is still fixed after this change

* Remove writing the `_defaultStyles` to the root of the webview page. These are only needed inside of the iFrame itself

data.title: terminating a debug session does not kill the launcher program but just the node process
data.body:
while testing the MERN tour Microsoft/vscode#22277:

terminating a debug session does not kill the launcher program but just the node process

data.title: "restart" for request type "launch" does a re-run instead of a re-attach
data.body:
while testing the MERN tour Microsoft/vscode#22277:

A "restart" in a launch config of request type "launch" does not only "re-attach" to node but runs the program again. This doesn't make much sense if the "program" is still running, like e.g. "nodemon".

So on every edit of "test.js" VS Code launches the program "nodemon" again: 
```
nodemon --debug=5858 test.js
nodemon --debug=5858 test.js
nodemon --debug=5858 test.js
nodemon --debug=5858 test.js
...
```

What should happen is the following:
```
nodemon --debug=5858 test.js
attach 5858
attach 5858
attach 5858
...
```

data.title: Debug hover does not work in some cases

data.title: MERN Starter Kit: Error reporting is inconsistent
data.body:
Test tour MERN - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22277

- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Mac

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open `index.js`, change any of the `require` to `require123` : No error
2. Open `index.js`, add `boohoo()` anywhere : No error
3. Open `server.js`, change `console.error` to `console.errr` : No error
4. Open `server.js`, add `boohoo()` anywhere : Error shown: `eslint: boohoo is not defined` 
5. Open `server.js`, change `dummyData()` to `dummyDta()`: Error shown: `eslint: dummyDta is not defined` 
6. Open `post.controller.js`, change `Post.find()` to `Post.fin()`: No error

Also, `npm run build` doesn't find any of these errors.

Meaning if there was a typo, user wouldn't know until the program is run.

data.title: Request  - Webpack IntelliSense
data.body:
Test tour for MERN starter kit https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22277

- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone MERN starter kit
2. Open one of the webpack.*.js files. 

I'm not sure how this could be done. A common pattern with webpack is to `module.exports` all the webpack configuration. If VS Code could give IntelliSense in that location (by maybe determining that its a webpack file) - that would be very neat.

data.title: MERN Starter Kit: Tests fail when run as task, passes when run in terminal

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Test tour MERN - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22277

- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Mac

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use `Tasks: Configure Task Runner` and choose `npm`
2. Set the below
```
{
            "taskName": "test",
            "args": ["run", "test"],
            "isTestCommand": true
        }
```

Now run the command `Tasks: Run Test Task`

In the Tasks output pane, you see 33 tests passed, 1 failed

Now run `npm run test` in the terminal. All 36 tests pass.

data.title: Remapped Escape key doesn't work anymore with Linux / Ubuntu (Version 1.11)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11 and 1.11.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Remap Escape key to Caps Lock with "setxkbmap -option caps:escape" in .profile - This way both Caps Lock and Escape can be used as the Escape key. Log out of user and log back in, so the remapping is loaded.
2. Pressing the Caps Lock key used to work perfectly fine in VS Code before version 1.11, now it only works with the actual Escape key.

data.title: Search issue with large file of single line
data.body:
This may be an edge case, but there may be something here to be improved.

I encountered some searches taking a very large amount of time compared to others which were nearly instant.  Tracked this down to a 3meg .map file that was appearing in results.

Looks like the entire file might possibly get sent back by ripgrep since it is one line.  Not sure if there is an option to trim the result to some reasonable length so that VS Code could better handle.

Work around of course is to simply exclude such files.

- VSCode Version: 1.11

data.title: The "Restart" action will start in debug mode after the "Start Without Debugging" action
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

After "Start Without Debugging", the "Restart (Debug)" action causes the program to start in debug mode. There is no "Restart Without Debugging" action implemented.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a static Go webserver.
2. Use the "Start Without Debugging" action (Cmd + F5).
3. Use the "Restart" action (Cmd + Shift + F5).

Expected Result:
The program is rerun without entering debug mode.

Actual Result:
The program is run for the second time, but in debug mode.

data.title: Debugging UI gets crowded

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start a debugging session
2. Add a bunch of breakpoints

![breakpoints](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/24818566/e111a0d2-1b95-11e7-912c-a1d3b17e378a.gif)

A couple ideas on how to handle this better. 
- There seems to be a lot of wasted space for the variables section. We could move watchers up as breakpoints moves up. 
- I wonder how often watchers are used compared to breakpoints. My gut says breakpoints are much more. Maybe we switch those two UI elements.

data.title: Code navigation highlights the folder inappropriately
data.body:
Test tour for MERN starter kit https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22277

- VSCode Version: Insiders 
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone MERN starter kit
2. Open index.js
3. Cmd+click near the bottom of the file to navigate to `server/server`

I expect to have the entire string highlighted, instead the folder is highlighted. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/24815287/790ab50c-1b89-11e7-902e-0b900236560c.png)

This is confusing as a user. It makes me think I am navigating to the folder and not the file.

data.title: Debugger breaks inappropriately
data.body:
Test tour: MERN starter kit https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22277

- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Git clone the MERN starter kit
2. Select index.js
3. Set a breakpoint anywhere in the file. 
4. Set another breakpoint in server.js
5. Start debugging

I expect to hit the first breakpoint and then hit the second breakpoint after choosing continue. 
Instead after hitting the first breakpoint I stop at an import statement. 

As I step through the code I am taken into modules inappropriately and then skip the breakpoint entirely. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/24814954/58f2a276-1b88-11e7-865f-31f478dce23d.png)

![debugging_issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/24815082/c93fabc8-1b88-11e7-9968-48a08fad6348.gif)
